data.title: Ubisoft reveals Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows, its long-awaited feudal Japan game
data.meta_description: Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows, once known as Codename: Red, sends the franchise to feudal era Japan in 2025. Ubisoft released the gameâ€™s first trailer, teasing more in June
data.text:
Ubisoft gave Assassinâ€™s Creed fans their first real look at the next flagship game in the long-running franchise with the debut trailer for Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows on Wednesday. Previously known as Assassinâ€™s Creed: Codename Red, Shadows will send the franchise to feudal Japan for the first time this November, letting players live out their shinobi fantasies as the ninja Naoe.

Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows will also let players take on a second role, that of legendary Black samurai Yasuke. While other Assassinâ€™s Creed games have featured dual protagonists, the two playable characters of Shadows appear to be more distinct than those of any previous game. The gameâ€™s female ninja character is shown wielding ninjato, wristblade, and kusarigama; her samurai counterpart is a heavily armored fella with a hefty katana.

The debut trailer for Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows teased its cinematic ambitions and introduced its characters. Fans may need to wait until Ubisoft Forward in June for a look at actual gameplay.

Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows is being developed by Ubisoft Quebec, the studio behind 2018â€™s Assassinâ€™s Creed Odyssey, under the creative direction of Jonathan Dumont. Shadows was originally announced in 2022 under its codename, and promised to send the Assassinâ€™s Creed franchise to one of fansâ€™ most-requested settings.

Shadows is the open-world RPG follow-up to last yearâ€™s Assassinâ€™s Creed Mirage, the scaled-back take on the 17-year-old Assassinâ€™s Creed formula. The feudal Japan-set game is just one of multiple announced projects in the works for the Assassinâ€™s Creed publisher. Others include Assassinâ€™s Creed Jade, a mobile game set in Chinaâ€™s Qin dynasty, and the mysterious Assassinâ€™s Creed Codename: Hexe, â€œa very different type of Assassinâ€™s Creed game,â€ according to Ubisoft executive producer Marc-Alexis Cote. Hexe is being overseen by creative director Clint Hocking (Watch Dogs: Legion, Far Cry 2).

Elsewhere, thereâ€™s Assassinâ€™s Creed Codename: Infinity, which is â€œnot a game per se,â€ Cote said in 2022, but â€œa hub that will unite all our different experiences and players in meaningful ways.â€

Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows is coming to Mac, PlayStation 5, Windows PC, and Xbox Series X on Nov. 15.
